Subject: Plackettâ€“Burman design
Value: an experimental design to limit the number of experiments covering the space by assuming the Interactions between the factors are negligible

Subject: prior art
Value: all information that has been made available to the public in any form before a given date that might be relevant to a patent's claims of originality.

Subject: factor
Value: a member of a minimal set of independent variables that can be used to model the dependent reposnses in a set of related experiments.

Subject: monotropically related to
Value: is thermodynically preferred at all temperatures

Subject: factorial design
Value: a design consisting of two or more factors, each with discrete possible values or \"levels\", and whose experimental units take on all or a subset  of the possible combinations of these levels across all such factors.

Subject: route scouting
Value: a process of systematically selecting possible syntetic routes to make a particular product or intermediate.

Subject: reaction process profile
Value: is a process profile that tracks some aspect of a reaction.

Subject: synthesis reaction time
Value: a temporal region that describes the length of time that a synthesis occurs.

Subject: process profile specification
Value: is a directive information entity that specifies allowed ranges recorded for a process profile.

Subject: quality specification
Value: a directive information entity that species the acceptable range of values associated with a material quality

Subject: CQA specification
Value: a quality specification set against a critical quality attribute of a material

Subject: profile of
Value: a relationship indicating that the process profile quantitates some aspect of the process (e.g. a quaklity of a material participant)

Subject: temperature profile in synthesis process
Value: critical process profile in synthesis process that is about temperature

Subject: starting material for synthesis
Value: a chemcial entity eith the role starting material in a synthesis.

Subject: intermediate material for synthesis
Value: the product of a chemiical reaction  but not the last step in a synthesis.

Subject: GMP starting material
Value:
a raw material, intermediate, or an AP chemical entityI that is used in the
production of an API and that is incorporated as a significant structural fragment into the structure of the API.

Subject: GMP synthetic process
Value: a synthetic process governed by the cGMP regulations.

Subject: temperature measurement
Value: a process measurement of the temperature in a process

Subject: charging material
Value: a unit operation of adding a reagent or starting material to a chemical reaction

Subject: enantiotropically related to
Value: a realtionship between polymorphs that has a cross-over temperature at which one form becomes more thermodynamically favored than the other.

Subject: GLP synthetic process
Value: a synthetic process governed by the GLP regulations.

Subject: stir rate profile
Value: a process profile that represents the number of revolution of stirs given a specific time period

Subject: material flow profile in synthesis process
Value: a process profile in synthesis process that is about material flow

Subject: quality process profile
Value: a process profile that tracks the quality of some process partcipant

Subject: filtering
Value: is a unit operation to remove portions of material from a synthesis stream by trapping it on a filter.

Subject: crystallization
Value: a crystallization is a process that has as a material output a crystalline solid or a mixture that has as an ingredient a crystalline solid.

Subject: polymer
Value: a substance or material consisting of very large molecules, or macromolecules, composed of many repeating subunits.

Subject: impurity fate and purge determination
Value: a process that determines the fate of impurities (organic, inorganic, elemental, or residual solvents) of pharmaceutical substances produced by chemical syntheses to ensure the desired product quality, and the ability of the synthetic route to  purge them.

Subject: route specification
Value: a sequenced plan of synthetic steps and defined intermediates to make a specific product from commericially available starting materials

Subject: synthetic step specification
Value: a sequenced set of unit operations for a single synthetic reaction or simultaneous reactions that are executed in a single equipment train.

Subject: fate of impurity
Value: the ultimate final state and location of an impurity in a synthetic process.

Subject: kinetic order
Value: a constant representing the concentration driving force

Subject: antisolvent role
Value: the role of a solvent in a precipitation or crystallization in which the solute of a solution is sparingly soluble to induce its solidification.

Subject: precipitate role
Value: the role of solids in a slurry

Subject: slurry
Value: is a suspension (AFM_0000442) that is a mix of solids in a liquid

Subject: crystalline state
Value: a physical quality indicating  the structural order of a solid in which its atoms or molecules are arranged in a regular, periodic manner.[wikipedia]

Subject: purge factor
Value: a result that quantifies the ratio of the amount of an impurity in the waste stream of a process to that retained in the product stream.

Subject: crystallization yield
Value: the ratio of the mass of desired compound recoved as crystalline material from a crystallization to mass of compound input

Subject: mother liquor role
Value: a debris role of the solution in a slurry resulting from a crystallization

Subject: crystalline solid
Value: is a slid with at least one crystalline phase

Subject: is polymorph of
Value: an object property that represents a relation between polymorphes that are polymorphism of each other.

Subject: route development optimization
Value: a route related process that is about optimizing a synthetic route.

Subject: route validation
Value: is a route related process producing data to demonstrate that a commercial route meets regulatory requirements.

Subject: reaction screening design
Value: a screening design to evaluate possible chemical reactions

Subject: process validation
Value: is a process of demonstrating that a process produces product of adequate qulaity and yield through the definition of the design space or risk assessments.

Subject: polymorph and solvate screening design
Value: a screening design to discover polymorphs and solvates of a compound

Subject: screening design
Value: a process chemistry workflow plan that specifies how a multi-parallel screening study should be conducted.

Subject: batch campaign
Value: a process of manufacturing one or more batches of a product in unbroken succession. It includes equipment turnover and cleaning can include dry-runs before committing the starting materials.

Subject: review of prior art
Value: an investigation of published material to find prior art related to a synthetic route

Subject: product filing documentation
Value: a document to secure permission or coninuing permission to marked a product from a regulatory body.

Subject: route related process
Value: is a planned process about a synthetic route

Subject: process monitoring
Value: is a process of measuring a quality of a material  associated with a process.

Subject: pressure measurement
Value: a process measurement of the pressure in a process

Subject: end reaction monitoring
Value: a process monitoring to determine when a chemical reaction has ended.

Subject: method of flooding
Value: kinetic determination method to determine the partial order of a reactant by measuring the concentration of that reactant with all other reactants in large excess

Subject: induction period
Value: is an initial slow stage of a chemical reaction after which the reaction accelerates.

Subject: assessed reactivity purge factor
Value: the assessed reactivity of the mutagenic impurity in the processing conditions

Subject: assessed solubility purge factor
Value: an assessed purge factor based on the solubility of the impurity in the reaction solvent and therefore its propensity to be purged in the mother liquors of steps that involve an isolation of the solid intermediate/product in that step.

Subject: unit cell quality
Value: is a molecular quality that describes the unit cell of the crystal lattice

Subject: space group
Value: a symmetry quality of a unit cell in three-dimensional space.@en

Subject: point symmetry
Value: a geometric symmetry that keeps at least one point fixed@en

Subject: polar point symmetry
Value: a point symmetry that contains a polar axis.@en

Subject: centrosymmetric point symmetry
Value: a point symmetry in which the original structure can be obtained by reflecting all lattice points through a single point.@en

Subject: non-centrosymmetric point symmetry
Value: a point symmetry of a structure that is not identical to any inversion of that structure created by reflecting all of its points through a single point.@en

Subject: enantiomorphic point symmetry
Value: a non-centrosymmetric point symmetry that cannot be rotated to align with the original structure (chiral).@en

Subject: non-centrosymmetric achiral symmetry
Value: a non-centrosymmetric point symmetry that can be rotated to align with the original structure (achiral).@en

Subject: unit cell a-axis length
Value: the length of the a-axis of a unit cell@en

Subject: unit cell b-axis length
Value: the length of the b-axis of a unit cell@en

Subject: unit cell c-axis length
Value: the length of the c-axis of a unit cell@en

Subject: cubic unit cell
Value: <a unit cell that has three perpendicular axes of equal lengths.equivalent to ENM:9000035>

Subject: tetragonal unit cell
Value: a unit cell that has three perpendicular axes, two of equal length

Subject: orthorhombic unit cell
Value: a unit cell that has three perpendicular axes, all of different lengths

Subject: hexagonal unit cell
Value: a unit cell of three equal lateral axes intersecting at angles of 60 degrees and a vertical axis of variable length at right angles

Subject: trigonal unit cell
Value: a unit cell of three equal lateral axes intersecting at the same angle but not perpendicularly

Subject: monoclinic unit cell
Value: a unit cell that has three axes of unequal length, two of which are perpendicular

Subject: triclinic unit cell
Value: a unit cell in which all axes are of different length and no angle is perpendicular nor equal to any other angles.

Subject: unit cell alpha internal angle
Value: a unit cell quality describing the angle between the b and c axes.

Subject: unit cell beta internal angle
Value: a unit cell quality describing the angle between the a and c axes.

Subject: unit cell gamma internal angle
Value: a unit cell quality describing the angle between the a and b axes.

Subject: unit cell volume
Value: the volume of the unit cell

Subject: unit cell Z value
Value: a unit cell quality indicating the number of formula units (molecules) in the unit cell

Subject: unit cell Z' value
Value: a unit cell quality indicating the number of asymmetric units in the unit cell.  It is equal to the Z value divided by the lowest Wycoff position multiplicity

Subject: unit cell crystal density
Value: a unit cell quality indicating the density of the compound in the unit cell

Subject: ICH Guideline
Value: guidelines issued by the  International Conference on Harmonization of Technical Requirements for the Registration of Pharmaceuticals for Human Use with the objective of achieving greater harmonisation worldwide to ensure that safe, effective and high quality medicines are developed, and registered and maintained across the world in the most resource efficient manner whilst meeting high standards. [ICH]

Subject: habit
Value: a description of one of the characteristic external shapes (crystal class / point group) of an individual crystal family / system.  Factors that impact growth rates on the various crystal faces produce different shapes but possess the same set of symmetry elements as parent crystal class.

Subject: crystalline solid thermodynamic phase
Value: a crystalline phase is a single solid crystalline thermodynamic phase

Subject: molecular complex
Value: is an object aggreggate of two or more molecular entities that does not include covalent or ionic interactions

Subject: solvate
Value:
stoichiometric solvate
(AFM_0001094)
A solvate is a crystalline material that has solvent molecules incorporated into the crystal lattice in a stoichiometric amount. [Allotrope]

Subject: hydrate
Value: a hydrate is a solvate that has water as the solvent adduct.

Subject: ionic salt
Value: compound is composed of ions held together by electrostatic forces termed ionic bonding.

Subject: anhydrous phase
Value: a crystalline phase whitout solvent in the unit cell

Subject: isomorphic desolvate
Value: an anhydrous crystalline phase formed experimentally by removing the solvent from a solvate

Subject: eutectic
Value: a eutectic is a heterogeneous ensemble of individual components whose crystal structures are like discontinuous solid solutions (phase separated).

Subject: concomitant polymorphs
Value: a heterogeneous solid solution consisting of two or more polymorphs of the same chemical entity

Subject: solid dispersion
Value: dispersion of one or more components in a solid matrix

Subject: point group symmetry
Value: a group of geometric symmetries (isometries) that keep at least one point fixed.

Subject: pedial
Value: an open,one faced tricilinc form with enantiomorphic and polar point symmetries

Subject: pinacoidal
Value: 2-faced triclinic form with centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: spenoidal
Value: a monoclinic crystal class with two nonparallel faces symmetrical to a 2- or 4-fold axis of symmetry that has enatiomorphic and polar point symmetry.

Subject: hexoctahedral
Value:
a cubic system crystal class with  48 equal triangular faces
 and three identical crystallographic axes with four fold rotational axes and centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: hextetrahedral
Value: a cubic system crystal class with 24-faces and  four fold rotoinversion axes and non-centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: gyroidal
Value: a cubic form with no mirror planes and enantiomorphic point symmetry

Subject: in-silico modeling
Value: an experiment  performed on computer or via computer simulation

Subject: Powder Indexing
Value: an in-silico modeling to predict the unit cell of the crystal lattice based on the powder x-ray diffractogram

Subject: crystal structure predictions
Value: is in-silico modeling to calculate calculation of the crystal structures by simulated annealing, evolutionary algorithms, distributed multipole analysis, random sampling, basin-hopping, data mining, density functional theory and molecular mechanics.

Subject: assessed volatility purge factor
Value: an assessed purge factor based on the relative boiling point of the impurity to the reaction solvent and therefore its propensity to be purged in the headspace of steps to which the impurity is subjected..

Subject: assessed ionisability purge factor
Value: an assessed purge factor based on the ionisability of the impurity relative to desired compound and therefore its propensity to be purged in the waste layer of a biphasic system in steps that involve such an extraction.

Subject: overal assessed purge factor
Value: the assessed ratio of maximum possible concentration before purging to its concentration after purging (the final product).  It is simply the product of all the assessed purge factors of each reaction step to which the impurity is subjected.

Subject: common technical document
Value: is a set of specifications maintained by the International Conference on Harmonisation of Technical Requirements for Registration of Pharmaceuticals for Human Use (ICH). for an application dossier for the registration of Medicines and designed to be used across Europe, Japan and the United States.

Subject: X-Ray diffractivity
Value: a chemical substance quality of a crystalline phase that manifests itself as a set of allowed and unallowed peaks corresponding to the diffraction of incident x-ray radiation as a function of the substance's unit cell and its space group.

Subject: bunsen burner
Value: is a heating device (environmental control device) that utilizes a open flame for heating.

Subject: fractionating column
Value: a device to separate vaporized mixtures of liquid compounds with close volatility.

Subject: Vigreux column
Value: a fractionating column made of a wide glass tube with multiple internal glass \"fingers\" that point downwards so that the vapor that enters from the lower opening condenses on the fingers and drips down from them.

Subject: Snyder column
Value: is a fractionating column divided into sections (usually 3 to 6) by horizontal glass partitions or constrictions each of which seats a hollow glass bead with an inverted \"teardrop\" shape acting as check valves, closing and opening with vapor flow, and enhancing vapor-condensate mixing.

Subject: Widmer column
Value: a fractionating column consisting of four concentric glass tubes and a central glass rod, with a thinner glass rod coiled around it to increase the surface area.

Subject: condensor
Value: a device used to condense vapors into liquid by colling.

Subject: Liebig condenser
Value: a condensor consisting of a simple tube surrounded by a jacket of cooling water

Subject: Allihn condenser
Value: a condensor consisting of a jacketed long glass tube with a series of bulbs on the tube to increase the surface area upon which the vapor constituents may condense.

Subject: Graham condensor
Value: is a condensor with a coolant-jacketed spiral coil running the length of the condenser serving as the vaporâ€“condensate path, providing more surface area for cooling.

Subject: Davies condenser
Value: a condensor with three concentric glass tubes where coolant circulates in both the outer jacket and the central tube to increase the cooling surface,

Subject: coil condenser
Value: a condensor consisting of a straight tube containing an internal spiral coil through which coolant flows.

Subject: Dimroth condenser
Value: is a condensor with a internal double spiral through which coolant flows such that the coolant inlet and outlet are both at the top

Subject: cold finger
Value: a condensor consisting of a vertical rod that is flow-cooled from the inside that is to be immersed in the vapor to provide a condensing surface.  This condensor is also used for sublimation.

Subject: Frederichs condensor
Value: a condensor consisting of a large water-cooled finger tightly fitted inside a wide cylindrical housing. The finger has a helical ridge along its length, so as to leave a narrow helical path for the vapor.

Subject: bulk substance quality
Value: a quality associated with a portion of material

Subject: environmental control device
Value: a device for controlling the envioronment of a particual space

Subject: heating mantle
Value: is an environmental control device used to apply heat directly to containers.

Subject: laboratory notebook
Value: is a document that is a  primary record of research used to document their hypotheses, experiments and initial analysis or interpretation of these experiments serving as an organizational tool, a memory aid, and can also have a role in protecting any intellectual property that comes from the research.

Subject: evaporation device
Value: a device that evaporates

Subject: chemical structure
Value: chemical structure is the structure of a chemical entity in terms of its molecular geometry and electronic structure.

Subject: flocculant
Value: a synthesis role used to remove suspended solids from liquids by inducing flocculation (the solids begin to aggregate forming flakes, which either precipitate to the bottom or float to the surface of the liquid, and then they can be removed or collected).  Flocculants, or flocculating agents (also known as flocking agents), are chemicals that promote flocculation by causing colloids and other suspended particles in liquids to aggregate, forming a floc.

Subject: CTA Section 3.2.S.1.1 Nomenclature
Value: the drug substance nomenclature section of the CTA

Subject: preferred IUPAC name
Value: a unique name, assigned to a chemical substance and preferred among the possible names generated by IUPAC nomenclature. The \"preferred IUPAC nomenclature\" provides a set of rules for choosing between multiple possibilities in situations where it is important to decide on a unique name. It is intended for use in legal and regulatory situations.

Subject: chemical abstracts name
Value: the name assigned to a chemical substance by the Chemical Abstracts Service of the American Chemical Society

Subject: chemical abstracts number
Value: a unique numerical identifier assigned by the Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) to every chemical substance described in the open scientific literature.

Subject: CTA Section 3.2.S.1.2 Structure
Value: the drug substance structure section of the CTA

Subject: chemical drawing
Value: a two or three dimensional representation of a chemical structure.

Subject: molecular formula
Value: a molecular entity quality which identifies each constituent element by its chemical symbol and indicates the number of atoms of each element found in each discrete molecular entity of that compound.

Subject: certificate of analysis
Value: a document certified by a vendor summarizing test results and specifications for a particular batch of its product.

Subject: appearance datum
Value: a desciption of a material entity based on a visual inspection.

Subject: CTA Section 3.2.S.2.1 Manufacturers
Value: the drug substance CTA section regarding manufacturers

Subject: synthesis flow chart
Value: a 2-D representation of a step-by-step progression through a synthesis or part of a synthesis showing reagents, intermediates and reaction conditions.

Subject: solution pH datum
Value: the measured pH of a saturated solution of a material at a specified temperature.

Subject: specific rotation datum
Value: the measured change in orientation of monochromatic plane-polarized light, per unit distanceâ€“concentration product, as the light passes through a sample of a compound in solution.

Subject: ICH M7 Assessment and Control of DNA Reactive (Mutagenic) Impurities in Pharmaceuticals To Limit Potential Carcinogenic Risk
Value:
is an ICH guideline and objective specification for the
identification, categorization, qualification, and control of these mutagenic impurities in pahrmaceutical products to limit potential carcinogenic risk.

Subject: DEREK Mutagen Prediction
Value: is an is-silico modeling based on DEREK that determines the risk of a chemical being a mutagenic impurity

Subject: MCASE Mutagen Prediction
Value: is an is-silico modeling based on MCASE that determines the risk of a chemical being a mutagenic impurity

Subject: rate equation
Value: an equation that links the initial or forward reaction rate with the molar concetrations or pressures of the reactants and constant parameters (normally rate coefficients and partial reaction orders).

Subject: Reaction Progress Kinetic Analysis
Value: is a subset of a broad range of kinetic techniques utilized to determine the rate laws of chemical reactions and to aid in elucidation of reaction mechanisms. While the concepts guiding reaction progress kinetic analysis are not new, the process was formalized by Professor Donna Blackmond (currently at Scripps Research Institute) in the late 1990s and has since seen increasingly widespread use. Unlike more common pseudo-first-order analysis, in which an overwhelming excess of one or more reagents is used relative to a species of interest, RPKA probes reactions at synthetically relevant conditions (i.e. with concentrations and reagent ratios resembling those used in the reaction when not exploring the rate law.) Generally, this analysis involves a system in which the concentrations of multiple reactants are changing measurably over the course of the reaction. As the mechanism can vary depending on the relative and absolute concentrations of the species involved, this approach obtains results that are much more representative of reaction behavior under commonly utilized conditions than do traditional tactics. Furthermore, information obtained by observation of the reaction over time may provide insight regarding unexpected behavior such as induction periods, catalyst deactivation, or changes in mechanism.

Subject: process analytical technology
Value: a workflow that utilizes online and at-line measurements to understand chemical processes by defining and monitoring ...

Subject: steady-state approximation analysis
Value: involves setting the rate of change of a reaction intermediate in a reaction mechanism equal to zero so that the kinetic equations can be simplified by setting the rate of formation of the intermediate equal to the rate of its destruction.

Subject: overall reaction order
Value: the sum of stoichiometric coefficients of reactants, is always equal to the molecularity of the elementary reaction. However, complex (multi-step) reactions may or may not have reaction orders equal to their stoichiometric coefficients.

Subject: concentration profile
Value: a quality process profile that tracks the concentration changes of a species

Subject: reaction rate
Value: the speed at which a chemical reaction takes place, defined as proportional to the increase in the concentration of a product per unit time and to the decrease in the concentration of a reactant per unit time.

Subject: integral kinetic measurement
Value: a kinetic determination method that measures the concention of reaction species which is proportional to the integral of the reaction rate.

Subject: differential kinetic measurement
Value: a kinetic determination methos that measures reaction rate directly.  (d[]/dt)

Subject: method of initial rates
Value: a series of experiments whereby the initial concentration of each reactant is varied while the other reactant concentrations are kept constant, allowing the determination of the rate order of the reactant.

Subject: graphical rate equation
Value: a plot of the differential kinetic measurement as the y-axis vs. the integral measurement as the x-axis.

Subject: Variable Time Normalisation Analysis
Value: a series of kinetic experiments that compare concentration vs. time profiles to identify product inhibition, catalyst deactivation and the order of components including catalysts.

Subject: mutagenic impurity
Value: is an impurity role of DNA reactive material that have significant carcinogenic risk

Subject: domatic
Value: a 2- faced open form monoclinic crystal with polar point symmetry.

Subject: prismatic
Value: 3, 4, 6, 8, or 12 faced monoclinic crystal with centrosymmetric point symmetry.

Subject: rhombic-disphenoidal
Value: four-faced closed orthorhombic form with enantiomorphic point symmetry

Subject: rhombic-pyramidal
Value: 3, 4, 6, 8, or 12 nonparallel faced orthorhombic system with polar point symmetry.

Subject: rhombic-dipyramidal
Value: 8-faced form orthorhombic crystal class with centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: diploidal
Value: isometric form with no 4 fold axes and centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: tetartoidal
Value: general cubic forms which only has 3-fold axes and 2-fold axes with no mirror plane with enantiomorphic point symmetry.

Subject: tetragonal-pyramidal
Value: 4-faced tetragonal form with polar point and enantiomorphic point symmetry.

Subject: tetragonal-disphenoidal
Value: a four-faced closed orthorhombic form with non-cnetrosymmetric point symmetry.

Subject: tetragonal-dipyramidal
Value: a  8-faced form with centrosymmetric point symmetry.

Subject: tetragonal-trapezohedral
Value: 6-, 8-, 12-, or 24-trapezium faced closed tetragonal form with enantiomorphic point symmetry

Subject: ditetragonal-pyramidal
Value: 8-faced tetragonal form with polar point and enantiomorphic point symmetry

Subject: tetragonal-scalenohedral
Value: 8-faced (tetragonal) or 12-faced (hexagonal) closed tetragonal form with non-centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: ditetragonal-dipyramidal
Value: a 16-faced form tetragonal crystal form with centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: trigonal-pyramidal
Value: 3-faced form where all faces are related by a 3-fold rotation axis with polar point and enantiomorphic point symmetry.

Subject: rhombohedral
Value: 6 faced closed rhombohedral form of six identical faces in which none of the intersection edges is perpendicular and having centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: trigonal-trapezohedral
Value: 6-, 8-, 12-, or 24-trapezohedral faced closed trigonal form with enantiomorphic point symmetry

Subject: ditrigonal-pyramidal
Value: a 6-faced trigonal form where all faces are related by a 3-fold rotational axis with polar point symmetry.

Subject: ditrigonal-scalenohedral
Value: an 8-faced (tetragonal) or 12-faced (hexagonal) closed form in which the faces are grouped in symmetrical pairs with centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: hexagonal-pyrimidal
Value: a 6-faced form where all faces are related by a 6 axis having polar point and enantiomorphic point symmetry.

Subject: trigonal-dipyramidal
Value: 6-faced hexagonal form with faces related by a 3-fold axis with a perpendicular mirror plane having non-centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: hexagonal-dipyrimidal
Value: 12-faced hexagonal form with faces related by a 6-fold axis with a perpendicular mirror with a centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: hexagonal-trapezohedral
Value: 6-faced closed hexagonal form with enantiomorphic point symmetry.

Subject: dihexagonal-pyramidal
Value: a 12-faced hexagonal crystal where all faces are related by a 6-fold axis. It has  polar point symmetry

Subject: ditrigonal-dipyramidal
Value: a 12-faced form tetragonal crystal class with non-centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: dihexagonal-dipyramidal
Value: a 24-faced form with faces related by a 6-fold axis with a perpendicular mirror plane and centrosymmetric point symmetry

Subject: ICH Q3C Residual Solvents
Value:
an ICH guideline for the use residual solvents (organic volatile impurities) 
in the manufacture of drug substances and dosage forms, and sets pharmaceutical limits for  in drug products.

Subject: ICH Q3D Guidance for Elemental Impurities
Value: a quality guideline for the control of elemental impurities in new drug products (medicinal products), establishing Permitted Daily Exposures (PDEs) for 24 Elemental Impurities (EIs) for drug products administered by the oral, parenteral and inhalation routes of administration.

Subject: one-factor-at-a-time experimental design
Value: an experimental design involving the testing of factors, or causes, one at a time instead of multiple factors simultaneously.

Subject: process safety
Value: developing an understanding of the hazards of a chemical process and developing methods to safely manage and minimize the risks of the process.

Subject: Boxâ€“Behnken design
Value: an experimental design to produce a response curve sufficient to fit quadratic models of the individual factors

Subject: Central Composite Design
Value: <a experimental design consisting of three distinct sets of experimental runs: A factorial (perhaps fractional) design in the factors studied, each having two levels;A set of center points, experimental runs whose values of each factor are the medians of the values used in the factorial portion. This point is often replicated in order to improve the precision of the experiment;A set of axial points, experimental runs identical to the centre points except for one factor, which will take on values both below and above the median of the two factorial levels, and typically both outside their range. All factors are varied in this way.>

Subject: laboratory notebook experiment identifier
Value: is an identiifer of a laboratory notebook experiment
